FutureLearn Category: Career Development , Learning by FutureLearn Category: Career Development , Learning As the world gears up for COP30 and governments race to adapt to climate change, one challenge we face is that we simply don’t have enough people with the skills to make adaptation happen. Here’s how we can tackle that. As the annual global climate conference, the UN Climate Change Conference ( COP30 ) gets underway in Belém, Brazil, governments, global leaders, scientists and researchers are meeting to decide how to drive faster and bolder action to adapt to climate change, and one thing is clear, there’s never been a more crucial time for climate action and adaptation . However there’s a major problem. We’re short on the one thing we need most: people with the skills to make adaptation possible. While demand for green talent is soaring with hiring rates for green talent being 54.6% greater than hiring rates overall (according to LinkedIn’s Global Green Skills Report 2024), demand greatly outweighs the supply. According to the World Economic Forum’s Future of Jobs Report 2025 , ‘despite a global 12% increase in workers acquiring green skills between 2022 and 2023, demand continues to outpace supply, with the number of job postings requiring at least one green skill rising by nearly 22% over the same period’. From supply chain decarbonisation, sustainable building and retrofitting to renewable energy and ecosystem management, recent government climate policies mean that green skills are needed now more than ever to fully lead the green transition and meet the climate goals that have been set. From diagnosing illnesses and generating content to transforming customer service and data analysis, AI is becoming deeply embedded in everyday business operations and our everyday lives. The growth of AI is accelerating rapidly. According to McKinsey , generative AI could contribute between $2.6 trillion and $4.4 trillion annually to the global economy. From AI, robotics and automation to information storage and distribution, it’s expected that these trends will have an impact on the sector, with the space for tech professionals continuing to grow in the coming years. title: Master Culinary Arts Abroad for Global Success
summary: The post Master Culinary Arts Abroad for Global Success appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: If you’re passionate about food and dream of becoming a world-class chef, you may be wondering: why study culinary arts abroad instead of locally? The answer is simple—studying culinary arts abroad gives you access to diverse cuisines, hands-on training with international chefs, and a rich cultural experience that shapes your culinary perspective. In today’s globalized kitchen, having international experience isn’t just impressive—it can significantly benefit your culinary career. Here’s why pursuing a culinary arts study abroad program is one of the smartest moves for aspiring chefs. One of the biggest benefits of culinary art schools abroad is the chance to study regional dishes right where they originated. Want to master French pastries, Thai street food, or Italian pasta? There’s no better place to learn than in France, Thailand, or Italy. Instead of reading about techniques or watching online tutorials, you’re getting first-hand training in the country’s food culture. That level of authenticity can’t be replicated in a classroom back home. When you study culinary arts abroad , you’re exposed to a variety of ingredients, preparation styles, and cultural traditions. This diverse knowledge not only enhances your creativity in the kitchen but also prepares you for a global culinary career. Your palate expands, your understanding of food deepens, and you gain the ability to blend techniques and flavors across borders. This is one of the best ways to develop a truly international approach to cooking. Employers in the culinary industry value candidates with international training. Why? Because it shows adaptability, independence, and a broader understanding of food and hospitality. Whether you want to work in five-star restaurants, open your own fusion restaurant, or become a culinary educator, international experience can set you apart. title: 10 Best Countries for Studying Health Abroad
summary: The post 10 Best Countries for Studying Health Abroad appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: Studying healthcare abroad is one of the best ways to gain a global perspective, practical experience, and exposure to different medical systems. Choosing the best countries for health study abroad programs can enhance both your education and future career in healthcare. Here are the 10 best countries to study abroad for healthcare, selected for their academic quality, cultural experiences, and healthcare learning opportunities. The USA remains a top choice for international students pursuing healthcare and medical degrees. With world-renowned institutions, cutting-edge research, and diverse clinical settings, it’s one of the best countries for health study abroad programs — especially for students looking to study medicine, nursing, or public health. Home to prestigious universities like King’s College London and University College London, England offers world-class healthcare education. Students benefit from the UK’s National Health Service (NHS), which provides an excellent framework for clinical placements and learning about public health systems. Scotland combines top academic institutions with a supportive learning environment. Known for its medical schools in Edinburgh and Glasgow, it’s a best place for health students to study abroad who want an innovative, student-friendly setting. Emerging as a cost-effective destination, Georgia offers internationally recognized medical programs taught in English. Students looking to study healthcare abroad at an affordable rate without compromising quality often choose Georgia. The Czech Republic is home to several universities with strong medical faculties and international health programs. With affordable tuition, excellent healthcare infrastructure, and a central European location, it’s a rising star for studying health abroad. title: How Studying Abroad Builds Key Life Skills
summary: The post How Studying Abroad Builds Key Life Skills appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: Studying abroad is more than just an academic experience—it’s a powerful journey of personal growth. Whether you’re heading to Europe, Asia, or anywhere in between, living and learning in a new culture offers you the chance to build skills that last a lifetime. So, what skills do you gain from studying abroad ? Let’s explore the most valuable skills you can expect to develop—and why they matter long after your trip ends.  One of the most important skills you gain from studying abroad is the ability to adapt to new environments. From navigating unfamiliar cities to handling cultural differences, you learn to think on your feet and become more self-reliant. This kind of independence prepares you to handle future challenges in both personal and professional settings. What skills does studying abroad give you that truly stand out in the workplace? Cross-cultural communication is high on the list. When you study abroad, you interact with people from different backgrounds and learn to communicate across language barriers and cultural norms. This skill is essential in our increasingly globalized world and can give you a serious advantage in international careers. Being in a new country often means facing unexpected situations. Whether it’s figuring out public transport or resolving a housing issue, you’ll need to think critically and solve problems on the spot. These are exactly the kind of soft skills employers value—making them a crucial part of the list of skills from study abroad experiences. The process of stepping outside your comfort zone builds confidence. Overcoming homesickness, managing your own finances, or succeeding in a foreign classroom can all make you more resilient and self-assured. So if you’re wondering what skills you can get from study abroad, don’t overlook the personal growth that fuels both academic and career success. Naturally, studying abroad improves language skills —especially if you’re living in a country where a different language is spoken

title: Study Abroad Destinations for Nature Enthusiasts
summary: The post Study Abroad Destinations for Nature Enthusiasts appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: If the outdoors is where you feel most alive, why not take your education to one of the best countries to study abroad for nature lovers? From tropical rainforests to scenic coastlines and alpine hikes, these locations combine high-quality academics with world-class natural beauty. Here’s a guide to some of the best nature countries to study abroad, selected just for outdoor enthusiasts! One of the most biodiverse countries in the world, Costa Rica is a haven for students who love hiking, wildlife, and sustainability. With its cloud forests, beaches, and volcanoes, it’s easily one of the top countries with beautiful nature! With snow-capped mountains, clear lakes, and remote beaches, New Zealand is a dream destination for nature enthusiasts! It’s a leading pick among the best countries for nature lovers thanks to its peaceful environment and strong education system. Green hills, rugged cliffs, and serene coastal villages make Ireland one of the most naturally beautiful study destinations in Europe. Its universities are globally respected, and the landscapes are straight out of a storybook. South Africa offers a blend of vibrant cities and raw wilderness. From safaris to surfing, it’s perfect for students who want rich cultural experiences paired with amazing natural beauty. A tropical gem in Southeast Asia, Thailand offers both academic opportunity and access to stunning beaches, jungles, and mountains. It’s a great place for students who want affordable living and year-round warm weather! With its dramatic coastline, forested parks, and charming cities, Portugal is one of the most underrated countries with beautiful nature. Students can enjoy sunny weather, hiking trails, and historic seaside towns. Colombia is a rising star for international students and a paradise for nature lovers. title: Study Abroad Anxiety: How to Cope and Stay Calm
summary: The post Study Abroad Anxiety: How to Cope and Stay Calm appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: Studying abroad can be one of the most rewarding experiences of your life—immersing yourself in a new culture, meeting diverse people, and gaining valuable academic and personal skills. However, it’s common for students to face mental health challenges during this time. If you find yourself wondering how to manage study abroad anxiety, you’re certainly not alone! Anxiety while abroad may stem from culture shock , academic pressures, loneliness, or simply the stress of adapting to a completely new environment. The good news? With the right strategies, you can successfully manage your anxiety and make the most of your international adventure! Below are proven tips to calm anxiety and practical advice for managing anxiety study abroad. Before diving into solutions, it helps to understand why anxiety happens during your study abroad experience. Transitioning to a new country can bring feelings of uncertainty and vulnerability. You might feel overwhelmed by language barriers , unfamiliar social norms , or being far from your support network . Academic pressures in a different educational system add another layer of stress, and these factors combined often trigger anxiety. Recognizing that anxiety is a normal response to these challenges is the first step toward managing it effectively. One of the best ways to manage anxiety is by creating structure in your daily life. When everything around you feels unpredictable, having a set schedule helps ground you. This can include: A consistent routine reduces decision fatigue and gives your day a sense of purpose and predictability. When anxiety strikes, it can feel overwhelming. Learning tips to calm anxiety like mindfulness and relaxation can help you regain control. Simple techniques to try include: These methods promote calmness and reduce the physical symptoms of anxiety, making it easier to face daily challenges. Feeling overwhelmed is common, especially during your first weeks abroad . It’s important to recognize your limi

content: Choosing where to study abroad for communications is a pivotal decision for any student aiming to build a successful career in media, public relations, journalism, or digital communication. With so many options, knowing the best places abroad for communication majors can help you make an informed choice. We’ll explore the top ten countries that offer excellent communications study abroad programs, rich cultural experiences, and valuable career opportunities. Communications programs abroad provide students with a unique chance to gain global perspectives, engage with diverse cultures, and build an international network. In a field that thrives on communication across borders, experiencing different media environments firsthand is invaluable. No matter your interest, the right destination will enhance your education and open doors worldwide! England is home to world-renowned universities offering comprehensive communications programs. One standout institution is London Metropolitan University , which provides robust courses in media, public relations, and digital communications. With London’s vibrant media industry, students enjoy ample networking opportunities, making England one of the best countries for communications majors. Croatia has emerged as an attractive destination for communications students seeking quality education combined with beautiful surroundings. ZSEM offers innovative communications study abroad courses focusing on media, advertising, and public relations. With a growing media landscape and rich cultural heritage, Croatia offers a unique blend of academic and life experiences. Italy’s rich cultural history combined with growing modern media industries creates a fascinating environment for communications students. Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore is a leading institution offering courses that blend traditional theories with contemporary media practices.
